text:
11 Lexington Avenue, north east corner and East 22nd Street, showing Ungrades Classes adjoining Child-rend Court.

Board of Education, N.Y.C.

1920.

Lexington Avenue, west side, north from 22nd Street. The building on the N.W. corner of 22nd Street is the Manhattan Trade School for Girls.

About 1920.

Gift of E. M. Jenks.

9 Lexington Avenue, at S.E. corner of 22nd Street. This was formerly the home of Mayor Abram S. Hewitt.

June, 1925.

119-101 East 22nd Street, north side, between Lexington and Forth Avenue. No. 119, the United Charities Building, is at the N.E. corner of Fourth Avenue and 22nd Street. These buildings are seen from 21st Street looking across the excavation where the 16-story apartment house 60 Gramercy Park North will rise. March 12, 1928. P.L. Sperr.

(1) 22nd Street, north side, east from Lexington Avenue. 137-143, the white builing with the Ionic columns, is the Children's [sic] Court. Beyond this building is the Gustavus Adolphus Swedish Lutheran Church, 147-153 East 22nd St.
July 7, 1928.
P.L. Sperr.

(2)
The same. The corner building shown on the left (No. 11 Lexington Ave.) will be demolished as a portion of the site for the annex to the Court.
August 5, 1937.
P.L. Sperr.

(3) The same.
May 8, 1938
P.L. Sperr.

(1)
Lexington Ave., at the N.W. corner of East 22nd Street, as seen across excavation at the S.E. corner of 23rd Street; the former site of the College of the City of New York. Building shown prominently is the Manhattan Trade School for Girls.
March 12, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same and showing the S.W. corner of East 23rd Street.
March 12, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

Lexington Avenue, west side, from 22nd to 23rd Streets, showing in foreground Manhattan Industrial High School.
About 1929.
Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

E. 28th Street, south side, east of Lexington Avenue. (general view northwestward).

A roof-top view across a low structure at the S. E. corner of the above mentioned location, looking towards the uncompleted Empire State Building. Obscuring a better perspective are office buildings at the S. E. and N. E. corners of Fourth Avenue and E. 29th Street. The low structures in the center are furnished room houses today and are at the N. W. corner of Lexington Avenue (right) and E. 28th Street (left).

February 22, 1931

P. L. Sperr
title: General view - [Manhattan - 22nd Street - Lexington Avenue.]

text:
East 22nd Street, at, adjoining and east of the N.E. corner of Lexington Ave., showing the Childrens [sic] Court, Nos. 137-139, adjoining corner structure, No. 11 Lexington Ave. The latter with the two adjoining structures, Nos. 13 and 15 (not shown) will be demolished and the site utilized for expansion of the Court. On the extreme right, and east of two 6-story tenements, is the Swedish Lutheran Church.
September 1937.
George D. Chinn.

9 Lexington Avenue, at the S.E. corner of East 22nd Street, (left), showing the home of the former Mayor Abram S. Hewitt, who was the son-in-law of the beneficent Peter Cooper. His son, Erskine Hewitt, succeeded to same in turn. The photographer silhouettes same against a background of apartment dwellings that face on Gramercy Park. Note the lanterns extending from the balcony over the portico. These are reminiscent of the old New York custom indicating the residence of the chief executive. A similar feature is to be found around the corner at No. 4 Gramercy Park West, the home of the former Mayor Harper of the publishing firm of that name.
February 4, 1938.
P. L. Sperr

11 to 15 Lexington Avenue, at, adjoining and north of the S.E. corner of E. 22nd Street (right), showing the former houses of Lucy W. Hewitt, A.S. Hewitt and Amy H. Green respectively. From 1926 to 1932 inclusive, the following were the owners: The Manhattan Trade School for Girls, Amy H. Green and Erskine Hewitt. In 1933 the Trade School title was transferred to the Frank Work Memorial. From 1934 to the date of demolition (Fall of 1938) ownership was registered as: The New York Association for the Improvement of the Condition of the Poor, Christopher H. Wyatt and the American Society for Psychic Research. To the left of the latter is the new building of the College of the City of New York. The Childrens Court on E. 22nd Street will erect an annex to fill the site between same and the latter feature.

February 4, 1938
P.L. Sperr
